Name: 3 switches, 1 bulb (find which switch controls the bulb)
Common Traps: Forgetting the heat signal; turning on two switches too long so heat signal becomes ambiguous.
Constraints/Rules: You may toggle switches any way; once you enter, no more switching.
Follow-ups: Generalize to N switches with one visit? What if bulb is LED (no heat)?
Key Insight: Use bulb heat as extra signal, not just ON/OFF.
Puzzle Archetype: Information gathering with one irreversible observation
Setup: You are outside a room with 3 switches; inside is 1 bulb; you can enter the room once.
Solution (Stepwise): 1) Turn Switch A on for ~10 min, then turn it off. 2) Turn Switch B on. 3) Enter room: if bulb is ON -> B; if OFF but warm -> A; if OFF and cold -> C.

Name: Bridge and torch (1,2,7,12 minutes)
Common Traps: Using fastest to return every time blindly; moving slowest separately increases total.
Constraints/Rules: At most 2 cross at once; torch must be carried; crossing time is max of the two.
Follow-ups: Prove optimality; variant with different times; variant with 5 people.
Key Insight: Send the two fastest as shuttles; move the two slowest together once.
Setup: 4 people must cross a bridge at night; times are 1,2,7,12; one torch.

Name: 100 prisoners, 100 boxes (each opens 50)
Common Traps: Random search is near-zero; stopping early; deviating from cycle rule.
Constraints/Rules: They must all find their own number; no communication after start; fixed strategy allowed.
Follow-ups: Ask for approximate success probability; explain why cycle rule is optimal among symmetric strategies.
Key Insight: Permutation decomposes into cycles; following your cycle maximizes success probability.
Setup: 100 numbered prisoners; 100 numbered boxes; each box contains a prisoner number; each prisoner may open 50 boxes.
Solution (Stepwise): Use cycle strategy: Prisoner i opens box i; then opens box with number found; repeat up to 50. Success if i is in a cycle of length <=50. Overall success probability ~31%.

Name: 25 horses, find top 3 with 5 tracks
Common Traps: Racing wrong candidate set (including D/E); forgetting that A1 is guaranteed top 1.
Constraints/Rules: Only race outcomes (order) matter; no timers.
Follow-ups: Variant: top 4; different number of tracks; prove lower bound.
Key Insight: After winners race, eliminate entire groups by dominance; reduce candidate set to 6.
Setup: You have 25 horses; 5 tracks; can race 5 at a time; want fastest 3.
Solution (Stepwise): 1) Race 5 groups of 5 (5 races). 2) Race the 5 winners (6th race). Label winner groups A,B,C,D,E by that race. 3) Only candidates for top 3 are: A1,A2,A3,B1,B2,C1. 4) Race those 6 using two races: race (A2,A3,B1,B2,C1) + include A1 known best; determine next 2. Total 8 races.
What It Tests: Algorithmic thinking without code; information efficiency

Name: Mislabeled boxes (Apple, Orange, Mixed)
Common Traps: Opening the wrong box first; forgetting all labels are wrong, not just one.
Constraints/Rules: Pick fruit(s) from boxes to correctly relabel all.
Follow-ups: Generalize to N mislabels; what if only one label is wrong?
Key Insight: The most constrained box gives maximum information; labels being all wrong is the lever.
Setup: 3 boxes labeled A, O, A+O; all labels are wrong.
Solution (Stepwise): Open the box labeled Mixed (since it cannot be mixed). If you draw an apple, that box is Apple. Then the box labeled Orange cannot be Orange (labels wrong) and cannot be Apple (already used), so it is Mixed. Remaining box is Orange. (Analogous if first draw is orange).

Name: Egg dropping (min trials, 2 eggs)
Common Traps: Equal spacing (too slow); binary search (fails because breaks remove egg).
Constraints/Rules: Egg breaks if dropped above threshold; breaks are irreversible; minimize worst-case drops.
Follow-ups: Extend to 3 eggs; derive exact k for N=100.
Key Insight: Balance outcomes by equalizing worst-case branches.
Setup: Given 2 eggs and a building of N floors, find min drops to determine highest safe floor in worst case.
Solution (Stepwise): Use decreasing-step strategy: choose k such that k+(k-1)+...+1 >= N. Drop first egg at floor k; if it breaks, linear search below with second egg; if not, go up by k-1, then k-2, etc. Worst-case = k drops.
What It Tests: DP intuition; designing optimal probing schedule

Name: 10 coins puzzle (counterfeit detection)
Common Traps: Trying ad hoc comparisons; not pre-encoding heavier vs lighter possibilities.
Constraints/Rules: Balance scale gives 3 outcomes each weighing; maximize info per weighing.
Follow-ups: Ask for minimal weighings proof; variant where counterfeit is known heavier.
Key Insight: Treat each weighing as ternary digit; pre-plan mapping from outcomes to suspects.
Setup: Identify a counterfeit coin among 10 using a balance scale (variant dependent: heavier or lighter unknown).
Solution (Stepwise): Canonical approach: with 3 weighings you can distinguish up to 12 coins when heavier/lighter unknown by assigning coins to weighings with ternary codes; interpret outcomes to map to coin+polarity. (In interview: state the coding method and walk through a small example).

Name: 100 prisoners, one bullet (prevent escape)
Common Traps: Ignoring assumptions; claiming absolute prevention without modeling prisoner preferences.
Constraints/Rules: Assume prisoners are rational and know your policy.
Follow-ups: Variant with imperfect information; variant with simultaneous attempt.
Setup: 100 prisoners can attempt to escape; you (warden) have one bullet; want to prevent any escape attempt.
Solution (Stepwise): Commit to a rule: if any escape attempt happens, you will shoot the first prisoner who tries. If prisoners value survival and only one must die, no one rationally volunteers to be first, so no attempt occurs. (State assumptions explicitly).

Name: 100 prisoners and a light bulb (island counting problem)
Common Traps: Letting non-counters toggle more than once; counter toggling wrong direction.
Constraints/Rules: Only one shared bit (switch); prisoners can pre-plan; random scheduling.
Follow-ups: Discuss expected time; variants with multiple switches.
Key Insight: One-time contributions + single collector ensures exact count.
Puzzle Archetype: Distributed protocol with limited shared state
Setup: Prisoners are randomly sent to a room with a switch/bulb; they must declare when all have visited at least once.
Solution (Stepwise): Designate a Counter who toggles switch OFF->ON exactly N-1 times and increments count. Non-counters toggle ON once in lifetime when they first see OFF. Counter declares once count reaches N-1 and sees ON turned on N-1 times.

Name: Crossword puzzle as screening (logic under time)
Common Traps: Random guessing; ignoring constraint propagation; not tracking candidates.
Follow-ups: Explain how you would implement solver; complexity discussion.
Setup: You receive a crossword-like constraint puzzle as a screening challenge.
Solution (Stepwise): Approach: fill forced entries first (single-placement constraints), propagate constraints, maintain candidate sets per slot, avoid deep guessing until forced; if guessing, choose slot with smallest candidate set and backtrack.
